title: Srimad Bhagavatam - Canto 1 Chapter 1 | Teens Quiz (15Q)

questions.prompt: In SB 1.1.1, what question do the sages ask at the start?
choices: How to gain wealth and social honor
What is the best good for people
questions.feedback: The sages ask about the highest good for everyone, not a temporary benefit. This sets the chapter goal: real welfare for the soul, not just external success.

questions.prompt: In SB 1.1.2, why is their question especially urgent?
choices: This age brings quarrel and confusion
People are born with perfect knowledge
Everyone has plenty of free time
questions.feedback: The verse describes Kali-yuga problems: short life, quarrel, and many disturbances. Because time and focus are limited, people need the most effective spiritual path.

questions.prompt: In SB 1.1.3, what do the sages request from Suta?
choices: A brief history of one kingdom
A method to defeat all enemies
The essence of scripture for this age
A new path beyond all Vedas
questions.feedback: They want the essence, not scattered details, because people in this age are easily distracted. The request is focused: give the most helpful instruction for spiritual progress.

questions.prompt: In SB 1.1.4, what is compared to a desire tree?
questions.feedback: The verse describes the Vedas as able to grant many kinds of goals. But the chapter will guide the reader toward the highest use of scripture, not the lowest.

questions.prompt: According to SB 1.1.5, what is called the ripened fruit of the Vedic tree?
choices: Rules for social law and citizenship
Lists of holy places and vows
questions.feedback: The verse presents the Bhagavatam as the mature fruit, meaning its message is complete and nourishing. It is meant to give the highest spiritual taste and conclusion.

questions.prompt: From the purport to SB 1.1.6, what blocks someone from tasting the Bhagavatam?
choices: A desire to serve the Lord
questions.feedback: The purport stresses that the Bhagavatam is best received with humility and faith. A critical, proud mood turns hearing into fault-finding, so the heart does not taste the message.

questions.prompt: In SB 1.1.7, what do the sages ask about Suta's qualifications?
choices: His learning and realization in bhakti
questions.feedback: They care about knowledge and realization, not status. This highlights an important Bhagavatam standard: truth should come from a qualified, experienced source.

questions.prompt: In SB 1.1.8, what method do the sages show for learning spiritual truth?
choices: Collecting money for a big sacrifice
questions.feedback: They model the proper method: respectful hearing plus honest inquiry. This is different from prideful debate, where the goal is winning rather than learning.

questions.prompt: From the purport to SB 1.1.9, why is saintly association so valuable?
choices: It helps one serve the Lord steadily
It makes one popular in society
questions.feedback: The purport emphasizes that good association strengthens hearing and service. It helps the mind stay fixed on the Lord instead of drifting into distraction or ego goals.

questions.prompt: From the purport to SB 1.1.10, what kind of interest is praised as real intelligence?
choices: Interest in topics about the Lord
Interest in political and social news
questions.feedback: The purport highlights a practical test: what topics your mind chooses again and again. Real intelligence is to prefer hearing about the Lord over temporary news and ego-display.

questions.prompt: In SB 1.1.11, what makes the Bhagavatam especially trustworthy?
choices: It was invented to fit modern tastes
It was spoken by realized authorities
questions.feedback: The chapter emphasizes authority and parampara: the message is carried by realized speakers, not imagination. This protects learners from trusting clever ideas over authorized teaching.

questions.prompt: In SB 1.1.12, what does the Bhagavatam reject as kaitava-dharma?
choices: Service to a bona fide guru
questions.feedback: The purport explains that cheating religion aims at personal gain, not pure service to God. The chapter trains you to examine motives, not just outward labels.

questions.prompt: In SB 1.1.13, what does sincere hearing of the Bhagavatam quickly develop?
questions.feedback: The verse presents a practical result: sincere hearing leads toward devotion and clear understanding. It is not selling status or power, but inner change and spiritual direction.

questions.prompt: Synthesis: Across SB 1.1.1-1.1.13, what method is repeatedly praised for real progress?
questions.feedback: The chapter keeps returning to the same method: hear sincerely from qualified speakers and ask honest questions. This approach builds humility and protects against confusion created by prideful self-made conclusions.

questions.prompt: Synthesis: What false path does SB 1.1 most strongly warn teens to avoid?
questions.feedback: A repeated warning is against covered motives: using spirituality for prestige, profit, or comfort. The Bhagavatam pushes for pure intent and real hearing, so practice changes the heart instead of feeding the ego.
